data.name: Calculation of the Angles of a Triangle
data.description: The task is to develop a solver that receives an array with the sides `a, b, c` of a triangle with the corresponding angles like the image bellow: The solver ```angle_solver()``` should output an array with the angle values in the same order. ```python sides = [a, b, c] angle_solver(sides) -----> [A, B, C] ``` The values of the angle will be expressed in degrees, minutes, seconds and decimal of seconds up to two decimal places (with rounded result), in a string format: ```"dd:mm:ss.00" ```, (not strictly, you may angles of 120 degrees, for example, and will use three digits, or may have minutes lower than 10.) For that kata you need the following formulas expressed bellow: ### Law of Cosines ```math a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc\cos(A) ``` ### Law of Sines ```math \frac{a}{\sin(A)} = \frac{b}{\sin(B)} = \frac{c}{\sin(C)} ``` ### Sum of angles in a triangle ```math \angle A + \angle B + \angle C = 180^\circ ``` You can easily get the condition of impossible triangles comparing the length of the sides(look the image) Let's see some cases: ```python sides = [14, 22, 28] angle_solver(sides) == ('29:31:34.55', '50:45:13.92', '99:43:11.52') sides = [14, 22, 35] angle_solver(sides) == ('10:44:41.05', '17:02:08.48', '152:13:10.47') sides = [3, 4, 5] angle_solver(sides) == ('36:52:11.63', '53:07:48.37', '90:00:00.00') ``` Enjoy it and happy coding.
